Award.AwardTitle: RR: Collaborative: Origins of Intergroup Perceptions and Attitudes Across Diverse Contexts

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Within the first five years of life, children become adept at categorizing others into social categories, which has wide-ranging implications for children's perceptions and interactions with others. Yet much of what is known about how children process social categories is based on studies conducted with limited populations (in terms of only including children from certain race/ethnic, geographical, and socioeconomic backgrounds). By harnessing natural variation in exposure to diversity in different regions of the U.S. among children from different backgrounds, the current project will lead to a better understanding of how young children from throughout the United States conceptualize and reason about social categories. A second goal is to test the robustness of past results regarding children's social category understanding and to contribute to recent calls for transparency, reproducibility, and generalizability in science.

The project involves five sites (Hawaii, the Southwest, the Northwest, the Southeast, and the Northeast), with each site including 4- to 5-year-old children from multiple demographic backgrounds. The focus is on four core components of early social category knowledge: children's attitudes towards; prosocial behavior with; facial recognition of; and perceptions of status of members of different social categories. Children will complete a standardized protocol and task battery that assesses each of these components across all five geographic locations in the U.S. The research will examine whether results are reproducible across geographic regions that differ in their demographics. It will also investigate how individual tasks relate to each other within each child (e.g., the relationship between perceptions of status and behavior towards children from different groups). This approach will also allow tests of the robustness of past results regarding children's knowledge of social categories and will contribute to recent calls for transparency, reproducibility, and generalizability in science. This goal will be implemented by: (1) posting all study materials so that the exact methods can be implemented elsewhere; (2) posting all final data so that others can re-analyze the data; and (3) pre-registering the proposed analyses in line with recent recommendations for transparency in research. By achieving a better understanding of the origins of intergroup perceptions and attitudes, broader impacts are expected to support focused interventions that promote positive relations between different groups of people.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

This grant funded a 5-site collaborative project investigating the early emergence of social category knowledge with a particular focus on race and gender in 4-6 year old children from a diverse range of racial/ethnic (Black, White, Latinx, Asian, and multiracial) and geographic backgrounds throughout the United States (Hawaii, Southern California, the Pacific Northwest, the South, and the Northeast). This study aimed to test the replicability and generalizability of children's attitudes towards, prosocial behavior with, facial recognition of, and perceptions of the social status of members of different racial and gender groups. With the data produced by the grant we are testing a wide range of questions regarding differences in these measures by geography or participants’ experiences with diversity, the role of status on the development of attitudes and measures of bias, the variability of outgroup attitudes as a function of one’s own group membership, and how different parent socialization practices relate to these outcomes. While individual past studies had utilized similar measures, they generally did so with participants in a single geographic area, with participants from only one or two racial or ethnic backgrounds, and with fairly small samples. By moving beyond these limitations this project supported the recent push towards a more open, generalizable science, or an understanding of which findings are more or less generalizable across these important forms of variation.

Across sites our project was able to recruit more than 700 participants from diverse backgrounds--one of the largest studies to date on social group understanding in the preschool years. Due to delays related to Covid-19, the results of these studies are still being analyzed and then will be written up for publication in a series of papers focusing on specific aspects of race and gender understanding. 

The project produced several other outputs in addition to these future papers. First, as part of the project, we produced and standardized many new tasks, all of which will be made publicly available once initial findings are posted. This will allow other researchers to extend our findings by using our same task battery in different regions and with different participant groups. Further, we will be making our 11 preregistrations public upon publishing each of those papers, as well as the analysis scripts for each paper, the resulting data, and a copy of each final manuscript. In this way, this grant was devised to advance not only the research agendas of the PI’s of this grant but to make materials available for other researchers who might want to use or adapt the measures for their own use and utilize the data produced for secondary data analysis. 

 In addition this grant supported the development of several junior scholars. For example, at the University of Washington and Yale, this grant supported the training of graduate students (who have since advanced to postdoc positions), full-time research staff members (who have since begun PhD study in the field), and multiple undergraduate students, in addition to the principal investigators. Still more researchers will receive training in the process of writing up and publishing research in the coming year, including postdoctoral fellows and graduate students.


Broader Impacts:

The primary broader impacts were in the training of a group of diverse scholars; the creation of a large database of findings that will be publicly available, and the advancement of our understanding of early social bias. As papers are published, we will publicize our findings in social scientific and educational communities to support increasing awareness of social disparities relating to social status, stereotyping, and prejudice. We expect our findings to be of interest to educators and intervention researchers who are concerned with reducing the negative impact of stereotyping and prejudice and developing opportunities for positive intergroup contact. Our group will continue to promote the widespread dissemination of our findings via op-eds and other media appearances, in addition to professional opportunities at academic conferences and meetings. 

In terms of training opportunities, several individuals who worked on the project as graduate students are now in postdoctoral positions and several individuals who worked as project staff are now PhD students. Thus, the project has advanced the career of a diverse group of junior scholars who are likely to go on to do research in this area. 

In terms of the database of findings, when released this will be to our knowledge among the largest open datasets focusing on early social cognition, including dozens of variables that can be explored in secondary analyses by other research groups. Further, the open materials we will release will allow other researchers to contribute to the dataset by using our materials to conduct research in different regions and/or with different participant samples. Thus, the project promises to yield broader impacts that go far beyond the specific research goals of the project team.
